channel.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
channel.description:
Well today was the first day of AP Comp Sci for me. One thing I'm sure a few of you will like (lare69, Strucker, Pure_, and Davidi2) is that we are going to be using Eclipse! Finally, I will be learning to use it.
One thing that bothered me was that the teacher said "You can't code on Macs." I was quite genuinely surprised by his statement because it's totally incorrect. I've been coding for like a year now and I've done it all on Mac.
Problem with this class is that it's not even a real challenging course. It's basically "Take this class if you dont know jack shit about coding!" Well over three fourths of the class doesnt know how to code which really sucks shit.
Overall I like it tho, teacher is funny, easy A, etc..

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:53, topic:546278”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=665177.msg4447234#msg4447234 date=1409456184]
wait how do they know what its written in if you’re just uploading the files via ftp
[/quote]
on campus students obviously do their work on campus in the tutorials/lectures, and the only software they are allowed to use is emacs… I follow the tutorials/lecture notes, but code in IntelliJ and external students submit their work to the professor via ftp… geddit?[/quote]

I’m forced to use NetBeans.
Spare a penny, sir?

Read full topic
item.source: First day of AP Comp Sci

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“PaulT, post:43, topic:546278”]I’ve been looking to get started with Unity for a while. How long did it take you to learn it? Have you ever tried UDK?

And I saw somebody posted that vim is the best, just throwing in my two cents for Emacs.[/quote]
It’s really easy. Just watch a series on youtube and they’ll guide you through it. I stopped using Unity for the time being because it doesn’t support java, only javascript, C# and ‘Boo’ which I have no clue what that is.

Read full topic

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“PaulT, post:43, topic:546278”]I’ve been looking to get started with Unity for a while. How long did it take you to learn it? Have you ever tried UDK?

And I saw somebody posted that vim is the best, just throwing in my two cents for Emacs.[/quote]
Emacs is great. Although when it comes to Java I whole heartedly have to go with IntelliJ IDEA. My teacher doesn’t let the oncampus students code in anything but emacs apparently, but given I have an external student and just submit my work via ftp, I just write my code in IntelliJ and copy it over haha

Read full topic

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:39, topic:546278”][quote author=Limits link=topic=665177.msg4447036#msg4447036 date=1409352504]

Well, look like I’m going to be the Teacher’s assistant for the year haha. I’m the only one in the entire class for 30 kids who knows how to code.

When I was in computer science I was basically my teachers assistant for Flash (yes, adobe flash) and HTML. He didn’t know much about HTML sadly…

Our curriculum for the year is java in eclipse, and then unity. I have experience with both so…
[/quote]
I’ve wanted to learn how to work with unity but haven’t taken the time to.
My computer science teacher taught the game dev class about it. Couldn’t take both sadly lol.[/quote]
Just download it and watch “Brackeys” unity survival game series on youtube. And Unity’s UI is very clean and easy to understand, and by hovering over things, it tells you in simple english what it does.

Read full topic

item.source: First day of AP Comp Sci

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:31, topic:546278”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=665177.msg4446907#msg4446907 date=1409282158]

[quote author=Jmood link=topic=665177.msg4446809#msg4446809 date=1409255773]

I’ve switched over from Windows to Mac OS X a few months ago and I have to say I’m pretty surprised with his Mac statement… I find programming is much better to do on a Mac imo.
[/quote][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=665177.msg4446775#msg4446775 date=1409246965]
programming on mac is like 3945978297 times easier than windows rofl
[/quote]im interested to hear the explanation of this, because saying programming is easier based on operating system sounds stupid as hell… only thing that comes to mind would be personal preference on the OS UI

My point was that many tools developers use such as git, ssh, and a shit-ton of scripting languages are already pre-installed unlike Windows where you have to do more work setting up the environment already. It’s also got some very nice web development tools that I use daily. It’s also got a much better UI and I think it’s more intuitive than Windows… Overall I just find it more suited to developers and designers than Windows.

  • Of course, this is all based on my own experience which I did mention in my first post.

If programming on OS X is easier than windows it must be a breeze on the superior GNU / Linux.
[/quote]This is absolutely true. On most GNU/Linux distros, installing a C or Java compiler is a lot easier than installing one on OS X. You can also write your code as the gods do, with vim of course.

not by much, and also doing C dev on os x is still way much better than it is on windows.

but yeah, brew is the shit.[/quote]

agreed

Read full topic
item.source: First day of AP Comp Sci

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:27, topic:546278”][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=665177.msg4446796#msg4446796 date=1409253631]
main reason would be that osx actually has a real terminal
[/quote]What would I need to use the OSX terminal for that I can’t in windows that is relevant to how ‘easy’ it is to program, and isn’t already handled in tools I use anyway (like eclipse handling git, etc). It’s nice that the terminal is there, but when I’m going to be using a third party program because it has more features anyway (putty, filezilla or w/e), it’s not really as relevant.

[quote author=justaguy link=topic=665177.msg4446797#msg4446797 date=1409253851]
My point was that many tools developers use such as git, ssh, and a shit-ton of scripting languages are already pre-installed unlike Windows where you have to do more work setting up the environment already. It’s also got some very nice web development tools that I use daily. It’s also got a much better UI and I think it’s more intuitive than Windows… Overall I just find it more suited to developers and designers than Windows.

  • Of course, this is all based on my own experience which I did mention in my first post.
    [/quote]Ok, setting up the environment can be an advantage. Unless of course you want to do any development with .NET But even then, when you take into account time developing vs time setting up the environment, it’s not really a big factor.

As for web dev tools, is that really a Mac advantage? There are a lot of good web dev tools that arent OSX specific UI is preference so that’s not really an ‘advantage’ overall.[/quote]clearly windows is turing complete too, so if you want to look at it that way then sure it’s just “UI preference”. I know I’d rather get shit done than piss around with windows (and I’m not just being a fanboy, I used windows for about 10 years until I used a mac and realised the error of my ways)

Read full topic
item.source: First day of AP Comp Sci

item.title: First day of AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:30, topic:546278”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=665177.msg4446809#msg4446809 date=1409255773]

[quote author=justaguy link=topic=665177.msg4446797#msg4446797 date=1409253851]

I’ve switched over from Windows to Mac OS X a few months ago and I have to say I’m pretty surprised with his Mac statement… I find programming is much better to do on a Mac imo.
[/quote][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=665177.msg4446775#msg4446775 date=1409246965]
programming on mac is like 3945978297 times easier than windows rofl
[/quote]im interested to hear the explanation of this, because saying programming is easier based on operating system sounds stupid as hell… only thing that comes to mind would be personal preference on the OS UI

My point was that many tools developers use such as git, ssh, and a shit-ton of scripting languages are already pre-installed unlike Windows where you have to do more work setting up the environment already. It’s also got some very nice web development tools that I use daily. It’s also got a much better UI and I think it’s more intuitive than Windows… Overall I just find it more suited to developers and designers than Windows.

  • Of course, this is all based on my own experience which I did mention in my first post.

If programming on OS X is easier than windows it must be a breeze on the superior GNU / Linux.
[/quote]This is absolutely true. On most GNU/Linux distros, installing a C or Java compiler is a lot easier than installing one on OS X. You can also write your code as the gods do, with vim of course.[/quote]

not by much, and also doing C dev on os x is still way much better than it is on windows.

but yeah, brew is the shit.

Read full topic
item.source: First day of AP Comp Sci

programming on mac is like 3945978297 times easier than windows rofl
[/quote]im interested to hear the explanation of this, because saying programming is easier based on operating system sounds stupid as hell… only thing that comes to mind would be personal preference on the OS UI

My point was that many tools developers use such as git, ssh, and a shit-ton of scripting languages are already pre-installed unlike Windows where you have to do more work setting up the environment already. It’s also got some very nice web development tools that I use daily. It’s also got a much better UI and I think it’s more intuitive than Windows… Overall I just find it more suited to developers and designers than Windows.

  • Of course, this is all based on my own experience which I did mention in my first post.

If programming on OS X is easier than windows it must be a breeze on the superior GNU / Linux.[/quote]This is absolutely true. On most GNU/Linux distros, installing a C or Java compiler is a lot easier than installing one on OS X. You can also write your code as the gods do, with vim of course.
